Many, many people are going to be forced to lose current benefits to spouses and dependent children or have people pull their suspension request and start receiving benefits sooner than they wanted.
It is first time benefits already being received will be declared illegal to continue for a certain segment of recipients.

From Bloomberg Business:

"Arguably, couples who file and suspend are double-dipping. They're getting the extra benefits that come from waiting until age 70 to file, while also accessing benefits early. Boston University Professor Laurence Kotlikoff estimates that file and suspend can boost lifetime Social Security benefits for many couples by $50,000.
The budget legislation calls file and suspend an "unintended loophole," and there is evidence that Congress never meant to create the strategy. The 2000 law that allowed it was the Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act, aimed at encouraging older Americans to work if they wanted to. The Obama administration proposed closing the loophole last year, saying it was an "aggressive" claiming strategy that mostly benefits wealthier retirees."

My husband and I are on SS and think stopping the loophole that lets people game the system is a sensible thing to do.

My view is that the budgets should always be for two years.  The budget should be proposed in the off election year (odd years) and run for two years.  This would prevent annual gridlock and Congress could use the rest of the time not spent on the budget to do what they do.

It does and will end any benefits (within 6 months of the bill's passing) that spouses and/or dependent children receive based on ANY person's record because of a file and suspend application unless that person lifts the suspension request and begin receiving personal benefits.

I know about this kind of abusive behavior from my experience as a special education attorney.  It is a huge problem in this country, and requires specific training for all teachers in order to put a stop to it.  Most of my clients are middle-school-aged boys with a behavior-related disability: ADHD or autism.  Both conditions produce students who are capable academically, but who have a much, much smaller capacity than the rest of us to control emotions, shift their thinking, and communicate under pressure.  The result is an awful lot of non-compliance.  It does require any authority figure to have a very strong ability to stay calm and understand that the defiance is not personal--it's protective.  That is a very hard skill to learn, especially when a person spends every hour of the workday issuing commands and receiving compliance.  The kid with rigid thinking, with frequent emotional overload, embarrassment in front of peers, and who is unable to express his needs or difficulties is not willful in the same way that a teen showing off in front of friends is.  But most teachers don't have the understanding of how their brains are processing the situation or the skills to manage the situation.  So, the kid is punished.  When the first level of punishment doesn't change the behavior (because the kid is still disabled), punishment increases in intensity.  This cycle continues to the level of abuse or arrest.  It happens every day in this country.  It is a huge problem.

Many are giving Kovie a hard time for saying the Mets are chokers but in one respect he is exactly right: at this level in professional sports in a championship series, it's a mind game - period. The Mets lost a tough one in Game 1 not only because it was a 14-inning loss but, more devastatingly, Gordon tied the game in the ninth with a bomb to straight-away centerfield off of "their" Mariano Rivera, Familia. It was a two-by-four to the back of the head. They lost the game five innings later. The Royals came out for Game 2 with supreme confidence not just for winning the night before but because they hit fastballers like de Grom all the time. The Mets were counting on a "Cubbie" showing. When they didn't get it, the longer the game went on without the de Grom strikeouts, and the longer they had trouble hitting Cueto's meatball pitching, when Daniel Murphy started talking to himself in the batter's box (and, big mistake, to the home plate umpire), that's when they let the mind game slip away.

Now, they're back at Citifield where they can regain the mind game edge. This is how comebacks take shape. One game at a time. But this is also where the Royals can show they are truly the World Series Champions of the Mind Game. After 162 games plus, we know these guys can hit and pitch. What's really being tested now are hearts and minds. Let's see if Kovie's right.

It's almost like the Mets should just forfeit the next two games and be done with it, so awful was their performance in game 2, across the board. Bad pitching, bad fielding, bad hitting. " The laws of war specifically forbid any order which constitutes a refusal to grant quarter."

Really? Where?

The Hague Convention on the Laws and Customs of War (1907), Article 23, section (d), to which the United States is a signatory.   The conviction and execution (by an American hangman) of General's Keitel and Jodl were based largely on their violation of that Article through their endorsement of the "Commando" Order.

This is really quite simple. The laws of war specifically forbid any order which constitutes a refusal to grant quarter. A number of German and Japanese generals were shot or hanged (by Americans) immediately after the end of World War II for violating that law.

This mission, however, seems to have been designed so as to deny the target an opportunity to surrender, regardless of any lack of resistance. This is clearly in violation of the Geneva Convention. And the only answer offered to that point is an assertion that "the rules change if Americans are the perpetrators, 'cause we're the good guys".

The second argument is essentially one of "my enemy's bad behavior justifies my own". I don't think further comment is necessary.

bin Laden may well have deserved to die. Lots of people do. But he was killed, while offering no resistance, by what were (effectively) highly-trained and well-equipped assassins in an mission designed to make surrender (effectively) impossible. A mission carried out on the orders of a single man, while denying the target benefit of trial or an opportunity to defend himself.

So let's be honest. An opportunity was seen to take the man out, and he was duly take out. But It was not an act of war. It was not legal. It was, in fact, judicial murder. And all the legal tap-dancing in the world won't change that fundamental fact.

The attack on the World Trade Center was a crime. It was carried out by a group of suspected conspirators, not by a state or state entity. Therefore neither the president nor anyone else could "declare" war on a group of criminals. The president can seek their arrest and extradition. He can seek the cooperation of other governments for their prosecution and he can refer them to the ICC in the Hague for trial under international law. But the term "war" has a very clear meaning and definition under both domestic and international law and the criminal act of 9/11 does not meet either definition.

We should be very careful to distinguish the all too often sloppy language used by journalists and politicians with words like "war" that have a very particular meaning in our constitution, especially in the allocation of authority between Congress and the executive branch.

A suspected criminal is not a "legitimate target" for assassination anymore than a soldier seized on a field of battle or a suspect of a crime whether citizen or not may be summarily executed. At least none of these steps may be taken by a nation that claims adherence to norms of international law or the US constitution. To be a nation of laws is the burden we accepted when we ratified our constitution. Neither the president, nor the congress can unilaterally change that and if they attempt to, they may be the ones who are guilty of what our constitution calls high crimes and misdemeanors.

Two not altogether insignificant points are raised here.  First, was there ever a declaration of war?  I don't remember this happening.  In fact, I think WW2 saw the last, and most recent, declaration.  Second, can a nation declare war against non-state actors?  This question has been raised numerous times.  Many maintain that 9-11 was a criminal act, not an act of war, and should have been treated as such.

The traditional common law definition of murder is "the unlawful killing of another with malice aforethought." President Obama asked his lawyers whether or not this particular killing would be a lawful one. President Obama did not, and this is the crucial distinction here, ask his lawyers to tell him how to get away with an unlawful killing.
